awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Greenland Geodetic Network (GNET) Research Networking Activity
awd_abstract_narration:
This project stimulates scientific interest in an existing facility and dataset developed in part by the National Science Foundation (NSF), Office of Polar Programs. This facility consists of 58 Global Positioning System (GPS) receivers located around the rocky coastline of Greenland, many of which have been collecting data nearly continuously for more than 10 years. This project fosters new and innovative research from these data by reaching out to science communities that include GPS experts and non-experts, or scientists that have not traditionally used GPS in their research. The investigators are increasing awareness of the facility and dataset and making the dataset more easily accessible. This project is important because it encourages innovative science from an existing large dataset that represents substantial investment of time, logistics, and funding by the NSF.

The Greenland Geodetic Network (GNET) is currently jointly managed by the US and Denmark. This project is developing a Research Networking Activity aimed at encouraging innovative scientific research from the existing GNET dataset. The project specifically 1) broadens community awareness of, and engagement with, the GNET resource through the development of a data portal; 2) encourages new and innovative use of these data with the guidance of a scientific Steering Committee that includes researchers both internal and external to the GPS community; and 3) provides guidance for continued GNET research and network maintenance based on input from the Steering Committee and community feedback, obtained at international conferences. The objective of these activities is to make GNET data more accessible to GPS experts and non-experts, with the express purpose of encouraging the science community to pose and answer new questions associated with this unmatched dataset.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Research Networking Activity (RNA) was developed to assess the use of the Greenland Geodetic Network (GNET) by NSF-funded researchers and to promote the network to new users. Thus, the goals of the project were to broaden community awareness of, and engagement with, the GNET resource, encourage new and innovative use of these data, develop international partnerships for GNET research and network maintenance, and provide guidance for continued GNET research and network maintenance. To meet these goals, the following activities were proposed: (1) creation of a GNET Advisory Board, (2) development of a new GNET website and social media assets, (3) presentations on GNET at international conferences, and (4) assistance in the coordination of GNET field activities.

 

Danish colleagues assumed management the overall GNET governance structure in 2019. This RNA helped a US and Danish collaborative team to establish the GNET Advisory Board to operate within that governance structure. The Advisory Board included the Danish GNET leadership, NSF RNA investigators, a representative from the EarthScope Consortium, and users of GNET data. These users were suggested from both the US and Danish communities and included investigators currently funded by NSF.

 

The RNA identified data discovery as a critical element keeping investigators from using GNET data. Thus, in the first year of the project the GNET website (go-gnet.org) was created by this RNA. The website was purposely created with the intention of shifting the ownership and maintenance of the website to Danish colleagues at the end of the RNA award period. This website provided maps, links and other resources to make high-end and casual users of GNSS data aware of: a) the geographic location of existing GNET stations; b) the current status of the stations; c) photos of the stations, so that users can see how the station is oriented and proximity to the ocean or ice sheet; d) data repositories of existing raw and processed (time series) GNET data; e) the current users of GNET data, in an effort to foster new research collaborations; and f) GNET events and contact information.

 

The NSF RNA researchers presented on the GNET resource at large international conferences during the award, such as AGU Fall meetings and EGU General Assembly meetings. NSF RNA researchers have also presented at smaller, more focused meetings, such as the Program for Arctic Regional Climate Assessment (PARCA; but now referred to as Future of Greenland ice Sheet Science Workshop, or FOGSS). Promotional material was also developed and included an informational card introducing the new GNET organizational structure and the website. And “go-gnet.org” stickers were created and distributed at various meetings.

 

The GNET network and the go-gnet.org website are now fully managed by Danish colleagues.

Modified by: Nicholas Schmerr
